There are all kinds of - you quote sociologists in your piece, Gregory Rodriguez, about - sociologists who want us to engage; they're worried about us ""Bowling Alone."" But obviously, people are finding ways to get together.
Well, the sociologists and the foundations that are spending a lot of time thinking about this I think - what I wrote my piece as a corrective.
I think a lot foundations who are turning their attention to civic engagement often want to get Americans involved in purposeful engagement.
They want them involved in the political system.
They want them, again, bowling in bowling leagues.
They want in organized activities.
What I'm advocating in my little, humble way in this column is that sometimes we - it's good enough to come together to do nothing, to actually sip a cup of coffee and to talk.
That's a level of civic engagement that is not on the radar of the foundations that are focusing on civic engagement, the most basic level of people talking to each other.
Just sitting next to somebody and looking at the newspaper and saying, geez, can you believe this?
